messageBody:
Sensorial Capacity is the term that i use to describe
a code that allows my transform groups to "sense"
others in some distance and act properly. Well, if i
understood it, i will need to put my code inside a
"already done" example and use it to test? Well, it's
a approach... I'll try to automatize as much as I can
it, but the artistic part of Java 3D, i think that
must be tested manually.

--- David Saff <saff@...> escreveu:

> Brunno Silva wrote:
> > Well, I worked a litlle with the J2MEUnit, it
> resolved my problems,
> > but i'm still working in some other questions
> about. Meanwhile, I'd
> > like to talk with you about Java 3D. I'm trying to
> make a little
> > exploration in sensorial capacity, but how to test
> it? Do I need to
> > make a Java 3D application inside the test or is
> there a more elegant
> > solution?
> You'll have to fill me in on what you mean by
> "sensorial capacity". I
> have some experience with Java3D. The approach that
> worked the best is
> similar to what UI people call "Humble Dialog": try
> to keep the actual
> rendering isolated to a very thin layer on top of a
> rich model. This
> way, you can test the colors, positions, and
> relationships of objects
> without even referencing the Java3D API. You may be
> able to get the
> rendering layer so thin that you can trust it after
> manual inspection
> and user testing, or you may need to use some other
> acceptance testing
> technique. Good luck,
>
> David Saff
